comment: We hope you enjoyed our video! Do you know that we have GIFs on this topic of protein folding---and many more topics? Check out our GIFs page here: https://www.amoebasisters.com/gifs

Watched: Primary structure- Protein shape - > protein folding Amino acids ( monomer of protein) Carboxyl group R group (Side Chain) Amino acid group  Seconday structure- Foldings Hydrogen bonds that can bond to an oxygen on another amino acid Tertariy structure- 3d shape R groups or side chains it can vary and define the amino acids and make them behave a certain way. Hydrophilic likes water Hydrophobic doesnt like water Hydrophilic hangs on the outside Hydrophobic hanges on the inside Quarterny structure Not in all proteins Chaperonins Some proteins are made up of more than one chain, or subunit. The quaternary structure is how these multiple chains come together and arrange themselves to form the final functional protein. Each protein has an ideal temp for fuctuioning, if the protein deals with something thats not in their temp range it can denature the protein causing it to mess with the other levels of protein structures, something it can be reversible and sometimes its not.

As a first-year college student who has been watching Amoeba Sisters for years... I just want to say thank you. You guys have turned science from a scary, unapproachable topic to something that I actually really enjoy now. I used to feel like science was too hard and that I wasn't capable of doing it beyond high school, but now I'm a biology major at one of the top schools in the midwest. And I'm still watching your videos to help me study. From the bottom of my heart, thank you.

Didn't explain what i wanted, though gave hope at first that it would be answered: What happens after the protein is created in the cell? We hear the protein does various functions but where and how? Does it go outside the cell, does it help create new cell, does it combine with protein molecules from neighboring cells?

Protein is very essential for the growth of the body, to repair damaged tissue, maintaining body functions and also mainly for the immunity system to protect you. Proteins are antibodies that kill bacteria, viruses, and fungi that enter the body.  They need to produce hormones that need to the function of the body. Almost all the enzymes used to digest foods are produced from them. They also help to transport various substances and compounds through the blood. As an example, Hemoglobin is a protein that transports oxygen from the lungs to other cells. Therefore it is very important to take a necessary amount of protein from foods daily. https://www.tipsforbehealthy.com/healthy-ife/importance-of-having-protein-rich-diet/
